intro: Peucedanum bequaertii, commonly known as the Kashmir angelica, is a perennial herb native to the high altitudes of the Himalayas. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its roots are often harvested for their aromatic properties and traditional medicinal uses. Peucedanum bequaertii is adapted to cold climates and is often found in alpine meadows at elevations above 3,000 meters.
